revision.text:
{{About|SSSIs in Bedfordshire|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:Houghton Regis Marl Lakes 12.JPG|thumb|300px|[[Houghton Regis Marl Lakes]]|alt=Houghton Regis Marl Lakes]] '''Bedfordshire''' is a county in the [[East of England]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/beginner-s-guide/eurostat/east-of-england/index.html|title=East of England|publisher=Office for National Statistics|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160113165155/http://www.ons.gov.uk/ons/guide-method/geography/beginner-s-guide/eurostat/east-of-england/index.html|archivedate=13 January 2016|df=}} It is bounded by [[Hertfordshire]] to the south-east, [[Cambridgeshire]] to the north-east, [[Northamptonshire]] to the north, and [[Buckinghamshire]] to the west.{{cite web|url=http://www.countiesinengland.com/|title=Your Guide to the Counties of England|publisher=Counties in England|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20161010173247/http://www.countiesinengland.com/|archivedate=10 October 2016|df=}} It has an area of {{convert|1235 |sqkm|sqmi}}, and population estimated in 2015 at 630,000, with an increase of 10% over the previous ten years.{{cite web|url=https://www.justiceinspectorates.gov.uk/hmic/bedfordshire/|title=Bedfordshire Police|publisher=Her Majesty's Inspectorate of Constabulary|accessdate=9 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304062903/https://www.justiceinspectorates.gov.uk/hmic/bedfordshire/|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} The county town is [[Bedford]], and the name is first recorded in the [[Treaty of Alfred and Guthrum|treaty]] in about 879 between King [[Alfred the Great]] and [[Guthrum]], which divided English and Danish territory by a line which went through Bedford.{{cite book|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/beds/vol3/pp1-9#fnn5|title=A History of the County of Bedford|volume=3|page=1|editor-first=William|editor-last=Page|year=1912|publisher=Victoria County History|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402160115/http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/beds/vol3/pp1-9#fnn5|archivedate=2015-04-02|df=}} Southern Bedfordshire is part of the [[Chilterns]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]]. North and mid Bedfordshire are undulating claylands with broad river valleys of the [[River Great Ouse]] and its tributaries, and the [[Bedfordshire Greensand Ridge]]. [[Jurassic]] and [[Cretaceous]] clays are overlaid by [[Quaternary]] glacial deposits of chalky boulder clay.{{cite web|url=http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/file/4984544973291520|title=Bedfordshire and Cambridgeshire Claylands|series=National Character Area profile|number=88|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=10 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151211130845/http://publications.naturalengland.org.uk/file/4984544973291520|archivedate=11 December 2015|df=}} There are forty [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) in [[Bedfordshire]], designated by [[Natural England]]. Thirty-five are listed for their biological interest, and five for their geological interest.{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=1&responsiblePerson= |publisher=Natural England |title=Designated Sites View: SSSIs Bedfordshire |accessdate=29 December 2015 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171124161435/https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=1&responsiblePerson= |archivedate=24 November 2017 |df= }} Three of the sites are also [[National nature reserve]]s, twelve are in the [[Chilterns]] [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]], and eleven are managed wholly or partly by the [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]]. In 2009 Bedfordshire was divided into three [[Unitary authority|unitary local authorities]]: thirty-two sites are in [[Central Bedfordshire]], eight in [[Borough of Bedford|Bedford]] and none in [[Luton]]. {{GeoGroup}} ==Key== ===Interest=== *'''B''' = a site of biological interest *'''G''' = a site of geological interest ===Other classifications=== *'''CAONB''' = [[Chilterns AONB|Chilterns Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local nature reserve]] *'''''NCR''''' = ''[[A Nature Conservation Review]]'' *'''NNR''' = [[National Nature Reserve (United Kingdom)|National nature reserve]] *'''NT''' = [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] *'''RHPG''' = [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of special historic interest in England|Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England]] *'''RSPB''' = [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] *'''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] *'''WT''' = [[Woodland Trust]] *'''WTBCN''' = [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire]] ==Sites== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" | Site name ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|B|Site of biological interest}} ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|G|Site of geological interest}} ! scope="col" | Area{{efn|name=NE|Maps and citations for each site are taken from the Natural England database. The area and location of the site is shown on the citation. The listing is as on 10 December 2015.}} ! scope="col" | Public access ! scope="col" | Location{{efn|name=NE}} ! scope="col" | Other classifications ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|name=NE}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Citation{{efn|name=NE}} ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Description |- |- ! scope="row" |[[Barton Hills, Bedfordshire|Barton Hills]] |[[File:Barton Hills - geograph.org.uk - 1337651.jpg|100px|alt=Barton Hills]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert|47.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Barton-le-Clay]]
{{gbmappingitem|TL088298|51.956|-0.418|name=Barton Hills}} | [[national nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]]{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves#barton-hills|title=Bedfordshire's National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001181940/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves#barton-hills|archivedate=1 October 2015|df=}} ''[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]''{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002165.pdf|title= Barton Hills citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 24 August 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150924130352/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002165.pdf|archivedate= 24 September 2015|df= }} [[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]] | {{Nature on the map|1002165}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002165.pdf Citation] |This is steeply sloping chalk pasture, which has a wide variety of grasses and flowers. A chalk stream along the valley floor adds wetland flora. Six orchid species have been recorded, including the [[fragrant orchid]] and [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchid]]. Another notable plant is the [[Pulsatilla vulgaris|pasque flower]]. |- ! scope="row" |[[Biddenham Pit]] |[[File:Woods between Deep Spinney and the A428 - geograph.org.uk - 89561.jpg|100px|alt=Biddenham Pit]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert|0.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Biddenham]]
{{gbmappingitem|TL023503|52.142|-0.507|name=Biddenham Pit}} | [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000892.pdf|title=Biddenham Pit citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924122905/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000892.pdf|archivedate=24 September 2015|df=}} | {{Nature on the map|1000892}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000892.pdf Citation] |This site has [[interglacial]] mollusk and mammal fossils, but it is uncertain which warmer period is represented. The lowest level also has [[Paleolithic]] stone tools. |- ! scope="row" | [[Blow's Down]] |[[File:Dunstable, Blow's Down or Downs - geograph.org.uk - 145589.jpg|100px|alt=Blow's Down]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 33.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Dunstable]]
{{gbmappingitem|TL032215|51.883|-0.502|name=Blow's Down}} | [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/blows-downs|title=Blow's Downs|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905154920/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/blows-downs|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=}} [[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifeextra.com/go/uk/blows-downs.html#cr|title=Blows Downs Nature Reserve|publisher=Wildlife Extra|accessdate=10 December 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151222141933/http://www.wildlifeextra.com/go/uk/blows-downs.html#cr|archivedate=22 December 2015|df=}} | {{Nature on the map|1005495}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005495.pdf Citation] |The site has varied habitats with a large area of unimproved grassland, which cattle help to maintain. Features include a disused quarry and medieval cultivation terraces. It has a rare plant, [[Bunium bulbocastanum]], and beetle odontaeus armiger.{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005495.pdf|title= Blow's Down citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 24 August 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304000359/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005495.pdf|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row" | [[Cooper's Hill, Bedfordshire|Cooper's Hill]] |[[File:Fir Trees on heathland - geograph.org.uk - 629499.jpg|100px|alt=Cooper's Hill]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert|17.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Ampthill]]
{{gbmappingitem|TL027378|52.029|-0.504|name=Cooper's Hill}} | [[Local nature reserve|LNR]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=110|title=Coopers Hill - Bedfordshire SSSI|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=18 February 2013|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304061600/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=2&N=&ID=110|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/coopers-hill|title=Cooper's Hill|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905153244/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/coopers-hill|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=}} | {{Nature on the map|1000484}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000484.pdf Citation] |The site is described by [[Natural England]] as the best surviving example in Bedfordshire of heathland on the thin acidic soils of the [[Lower Greensand Group|Lower Greensand Ridge]]. It also has areas of marsh and woodland.{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000484.pdf|title=Cooper's Hill citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304071404/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000484.pdf|archivedate=4 March 2016|df=}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Deacon Hill SSSI]] |[[File:Deacon Hill, Bedfordshire 9.JPG|100px|alt=Deacon Hill]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 35.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Pegsdon]]
{{gbmappingitem|TL121295|51.953|-0.37|name=Deacon Hill}} | [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/pegsdon-hills-and-hoo-bit|title=Pegsdon Hills and Hoo Bit|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=24 August 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905151557/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/pegsdon-hills-and-hoo-bit|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url= http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271000490%27|title= Map of Deacon Hill|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 24 August 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160121081543/http://magic.defra.gov.uk/MagicMap.aspx?startTopic=Designations&activelayer=sssiIndex&query=HYPERLINK%3D%271000490%27|archivedate= 21 January 2016|df= }} [[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]]{{cite web|url=http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/blog/2011/04/cycling-in-the-chilterns/|title=Cycling in the Chilterns|publisher=Ordnance Survey|accessdate=10 December 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150706233017/http://www.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/blog/2011/04/cycling-in-the-chilterns/|archivedate=2015-07-06|df=}} | {{Nature on the map|1000490}} | [https://web.archive.org/web/20150402162805/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000490.pdf Citation] |The site is [[calcareous]] grassland which is rich in plant species, some of which are uncommon. Birds include lapwings and buzzards, and there are butterflies such as [[dingy skipper|dingy]] and [[Pyrgus malvae|grizzled skippers]]. {{gbmappingitem|TL005276|51.938|-0.54|name=Dropshort Marsh}} | [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|WTBCN]]{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/dropshort-marsh|title=Dropshort Marsh|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=25 August 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150905152905/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/dropshort-marsh|archivedate=5 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} | {{Nature on the map|1002711}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002711.pdf Citation] |This marsh has a variety of habitats, including a scarce [[quaking bog]]. The ancient [[strip lynchet]] field system is of archaeological interest.{{cite web|url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves|title=Bedfordshire's National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=8 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402122715/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves/bedfordshires-national-nature-reserves|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002999.pdf|title=Knocking Hoe citation|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=8 March 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402134628/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1002999.pdf|archivedate=2 April 2015|df=}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Marston Thrift]] |[[File:Marston Thrift 7.JPG|100px|alt=Marston Thrift]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 37.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Cranfield]]

Grass species include [[red fescue]] and [[sweet vernal-grass]].{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000819.pdf|title= Tilwick Meadow citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 4 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150924122838/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000819.pdf|archivedate= 24 September 2015|df= }} |- ! scope="row" | [[Totternhoe Chalk Quarry]] |[[File:Totternhoe Chalk Quarry 5.JPG|100px|alt=Totternhoe Chalk Quarry]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert|13.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Totternhoe]]

{{gbmappingitem|SP978220|51.888|-0.58|name=Totternhoe Knolls}} | [[Local nature reserve|LNR]]{{cite web|url=http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/Special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=totternhoe&ID=471|title=Totternhoe Knolls|series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|date=9 February 2013|accessdate=9 September 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925113227/http://www.lnr.naturalengland.org.uk/special/lnr/lnr_details.asp?C=0&N=Totternhoe&ID=471|archivedate=25 September 2015|df=}} [[Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|WTBCN]] [[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]] | {{Nature on the map|1001561}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001561.pdf Citation] |This is grassland with a rich variety of plant species, including some that are now rare. There are a number of orchids and a wide variety of invertebrates, including butterflies such as the [[common blue]], [[chalkhill blue]], and the scarce [[small blue]] and [[Hamearis lucina|Duke of Burgundy]].{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001561.pdf|title= Totternhoe Knolls citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 10 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20150924124900/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001561.pdf|archivedate= 24 September 2015|df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/totternhoe-knolls-and-quarry|title=Totternhoe|publisher=Wildlife Trust for Bedfordshire, Cambridgeshire and Northamptonshire|accessdate=10 September 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150926110945/http://www.wildlifebcn.org/reserves/totternhoe-knolls-and-quarry|archivedate=26 September 2015|df=dmy-all}} |- ! scope="row" | [[Totternhoe Stone Pit]] |[[File:Totternhoe Stone Pit.JPG|100px|alt=Totternhoe Stone Pit]] | | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |NO | [[Totternhoe]]
{{gbmappingitem|SP980222|51.89|-0.577|name=Totternhoe Stone Pit}} | [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000166.pdf|title= Totternhoe Stone Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 6 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151208145812/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000166.pdf|archivedate= 8 December 2015|df= }} [[Chilterns AONB|CAONB]] | {{Nature on the map|2000166}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000166.pdf Citation] |The site displays the base of the [[Totternhoe Stone]]. It is a lime mud with an extensive deposit of late [[Cretaceous]] shark teeth, some of species which have not been fully described, so it will be an important resource for further research.{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000166.pdf|title= Totternhoe Stone Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 6 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20151208145812/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000166.pdf|archivedate= 8 December 2015|df= }} |- ! scope="row" | [[Wavendon Heath Ponds]] |[[File:Wavendon Heath Ponds 7.JPG|100px|alt=Wavendon Heath Ponds]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert|4.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |YES | [[Aspley Heath]]
{{gbmappingitem|SP930338|51.995|-0.647|name=Wavendon Heath Ponds}} | | {{Nature on the map|1001584}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001584.pdf Citation] |The site is acidic [[mire]]. It has three ponds which have unusual plant communities, two unimproved meadows, some damp birch woodland and a small stream.{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001584.pdf|title= Wavendon Heath Ponds citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 2 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304001635/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1001584.pdf|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }} |- ! scope="row" | [[Yelden Meadows]] |[[File:Yelden Meadows.JPG|100px|alt=Yelden Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | | {{convert| 2.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on}} |NO | [[Yelden]]
{{gbmappingitem|TL009673|52.295|-0.522|name=Yelden Meadows}} | | {{Nature on the map|1005059}} | [http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005059.pdf Citation] |The site is a rare example of neutral grassland on clay which has not been improved agriculturally. It is a flood meadow which has been maintained to provide hay with grazing during the winter, and it has a rich variety of plant species.{{cite web|url= http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005059.pdf|title= Yelden Meadows citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher= Natural England|accessdate= 6 September 2015|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20160304003602/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1005059.pdf|archivedate= 4 March 2016|df= }} |} ==See also== {{Commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Bedfordshire}} *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Bedfordshire]] *[[National Nature Reserves in Bedfordshire]] ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} {{SSSIs Bedfordshire}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} {{Featured list}} {{Coord|52|05|N|0|25|W|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Bedfordshire| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Bedfordshire]] [[Category:Bedfordshire-related lists|Sites of Special]]

page.title: List of Solar System objects by greatest aphelion

revision.comment: /* Greatest barycentric aphelion */ Add 2015 TG387; update 2014 FE72 (longer data arc); new standard epoch for rest of table
revision.text:
{{Cleanup|date=May 2016|reason=Article is written too technically, with no explanation of terms such as "Barycentric value in 2200", etc.}} [[File:Sedna orbit.svg|thumb|The orbit of Sedna (red) set against the orbits of outer Solar System objects (Pluto's orbit is purple).|alt=The orbit of Sedna lies well beyond these objects, and extends many times their distances from the Sun]] This is a '''list of Solar System objects by greatest aphelion''' or the greatest distance from the Sun that the orbit takes it. For the purposes of this list, it is implied that the object is orbiting the Sun [[Two-body problem|in a two-body solution]] without the influence of the planets or passing stars. The aphelion can change significantly due to the gravitational influence of planets and other stars. Most of these objects are comets on a calculated path and may not be directly observable. For instance, comet [[Comet Hale–Bopp|Hale-Bopp]] was last seen in 2013 at [[apparent magnitude|magnitude]] 24{{cite web|url=https://minorplanetcenter.net/db_search/show_object?utf8=%E2%9C%93&object_id=C%2F1995+O1| title=C/1995 O1 (Hale-Bopp)| publisher=Minor Planet Center| accessdate=14 March 2018}} and continues to fade, making it invisible to all but the most powerful telescopes. The maximum extent of the region in which the Sun's [[gravitational field]] is dominant, the [[Hill sphere]], may extend to {{convert|230000|AU|ly|abbr=off}} as calculated in the 1960s.{{Citation|last = Chebotarev|first = G.A.|title = Gravitational Spheres of the Major Planets, Moon and Sun|journal = Soviet Astronomy|volume = 7|issue = 5|pages = 618–622|year = 1964|accessdate = |bibcode = 1964SvA.....7..618C}} But any comet currently more than about {{convert|150000|AU|ly|abbr=on|lk=on|sigfig=1}} from the Sun can be considered lost to the [[interstellar medium]]. The nearest known star is Proxima Centauri at 271,000 AU which is 4.22 light years,[http://imagine.gsfc.nasa.gov/features/cosmic/nearest_star_info.html NASA – Imagine the Universe: The Nearest Star] followed by Alpha Centauri at about 4.35 light years away according to NASA. Comets are thought to orbit the Sun at great distances, but then be perturbed by passing stars and the [[galactic tide]]s.[http://www.phys.vt.edu/~jhs/faq/astronomy.html Frequently Asked Questions About General Astronomy ] As they come into or leave the inner Solar System they may have their orbit changed by the planets, or alternatively be ejected from the Solar System. It is also possible they may collide with the Sun or a planet. ==Comets with greatest aphelion (2 body heliocentric)== The exact furthest distance from the Sun (aphelion) can be very different depending on the object's position in its orbit, as well as the [[epoch (astronomy)|epoch]]. An incoming asteroid could be slowed down by Jupiter, making its orbit closer to the Sun. The aphelion distance for heliocentric orbits (only taking into account the present location of the Sun as the orbited mass) can be highly inaccurate for objects with an [[orbital eccentricity]] approaching 1 (a hyperbolic orbit not bound to the Solar System) especially when the orbit is calculated while the object is near its closest point to the Sun and has not left the planetary region of the Solar System, where it passes closest to planets which could alter its orbit significantly. Barycentric solutions are more accurate because they account for the combined gravity of the Sun and the most massive planet Jupiter. An epoch of 2200 has all of these objects well outside of the planetary region of the Solar System. In 2200, comet C/2012 S4 will be {{Convert|178|AU|e9km|sigfig=2|abbr=unit|lk=on}} from the Sun. It should be noted that the exact position of [[Planet Nine]] is poorly known, so some comets might have been slightly perturbed by it. However, statistically only 0.17% of distant comets should pass less than 100 AU from planet Nine, and only 0.0017% less than 10 AU. [[File:Comet 1910 A1.jpg|thumb|C/1910 A1 during its 1910 close approach]] [[File:New shot of Proxima Centauri, our nearest neighbour.jpg|thumb|[[Proxima Centauri]] is 271,000 AU or 4.25 light years away]] {| class="wikitable" ! *[[C/2006 Q1]] (McNaught) 13768 *[[C/2014 Q6]] (PANSTARRS) 13761 *[[C/1975 V1-A]] (West) 13560 *[[C/1999 F1]] (Catalina) 13390 === Distant periodic comets with well-known aphelion === {{further|List of Halley-type comets}} [[File:AnimatedOrbitOf1PHalley.gif|thumb|The orbital paths of Halley, outlined in blue, against the orbits of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune, outlined in red.]] These can also change significantly such as if perturbed by Jupiter *[[153P/Ikeya–Zhang]] (0.5–102) *[[273P/Pons–Gambart]] (0.8–63) *[[35P/Herschel–Rigollet]] (0.7–57 AU, returns in 2092) *[[Comet Swift–Tuttle]] (0.96-51 AU) *[[177P/Barnard]] (1–47) *[[Halley's Comet]][http://www.oarval.org/furthest.htm Furthest SSB] (0.59-35, for many years the most distant aphelion known) *[[165P/LINEAR]] (7–29) *[[122P/de Vico]] (0.6–34) *[[12P/Pons–Brooks]] (0.7–33.5) [[File:Orbits of periodic comets.svg|thumb|left|450px|The orbits of three [[periodic comet]]s, [[Halley's Comet|Halley]], [[19P/Borrelly|Borrelly]] and [[153P/Ikeya–Zhang|Ikeya–Zhang]], set against the orbits of the [[outer planets]]. Ikeya–Zhang is to the right.|alt=The orbital paths of three comets, outlined in turquoise, against the orbits of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune, outlined in green]] {{clear}} === Distant comets with long observation arcs and/or barycentric === [[File:C-west-1976-ps.jpg|thumb|Comet West in 1976]] Examples of comets with a more well-determined orbit. Comets are extremely small relative to other bodies and hard to observe once they stop outgassing (see [[Coma (cometary)]]). Because they are typically discovered close to the Sun, it will take some time even thousands of years for them to actually travel out to great distances. The [[Whipple (spacecraft)|''Whipple'']] proposal might be able to detect Oort cloud objects at great distances, but probably not a particular object. {{Div col|colwidth=26em}} *[[Comet West]] 70,000 [[Astronomical unit|AU]]{{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=C/1975+V1 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/1975 V1-A (West) |accessdate=2011-02-01}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) (1.1 [[light-year]]s) *[[C/1999 F1]] (Catalina) 66,600 [[Astronomical Unit|AU]]{{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=C/1999+F1 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/1999 F1 (Catalina) |accessdate=2011-03-07}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]] and [[Barycentric coordinates (astronomy)|barycentric coordinates]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) (1.05 [[light-year]]s) *[[C/2012 S4 (PANSTARRS)|C/2012 S4]] (PANSTARRS) 5700 AU (barycentric) {{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=2012S4 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/2012 S4 (PANSTARRS) |accessdate=2015-09-26}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]] and [[Barycentric coordinates (astronomy)|barycentric coordinates]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) *[[Comet Hyakutake]] (C/1996 B2) 3410 [[Astronomical Unit|AU]]{{cite web |date=2011-01-30 |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://home.comcast.net/~kpheider/Hyakutake-70kyr.txt |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet Hyakutake (C/1996 B2) |accessdate=2011-01-30}} ([http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=C/1996+B2 Horizons]) *[[C/1910 A1]] (Great January comet) about 2974 AU (barycentric){{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=C/1910+A1 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/1910 A1 (Great January comet) |accessdate=2011-02-07}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]] and [[Barycentric coordinates (astronomy)|barycentric coordinates]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) *[[C/1992 J1]] (Spacewatch) 3650 AU{{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=C/1992+J1 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet C/1992 J1 (Spacewatch) |accessdate=7 October 2012}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]] and [[Barycentric coordinates (astronomy)|barycentric coordinates]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) *[[Comet Lulin|C/2007 N3]] (Lulin) 2400{{cite web |author=[[JPL Horizons On-Line Ephemeris System|Horizons]] output |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/horizons.cgi?find_body=1&body_group=sb&sstr=C/2007+N3 |title=Barycentric Osculating Orbital Elements for Comet Lulin (C/2007 N3) |accessdate=2011-01-30}} (Solution using the Solar System [[Center of mass#Barycenter in astrophysics and astronomy|Barycenter]]. Select Ephemeris Type:Elements and Center:@0) {{Div col end}} == Minor planets == {{See also|List of trans-Neptunian objects}} A large number of [[trans-Neptunian objects]] (TNOs) – [[minor planet]]s orbiting beyond the orbit of [[Neptune]] – have been discovered in recent years. Many TNOs have orbits with an aphelion (farthest distance to the Sun) far beyond Neptune's orbit at 30.1 [[Astronomical units|AU]]. Some of these TNOs with an extreme aphelion are [[detached object]]s such as {{mpl|2010 GB|174}}, which always reside in the outermost region of the Solar System, while for other TNOs, the extreme aphelion is due to an exceptionally high [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] such as for {{mpl|2005 VX|3}}, which orbits the Sun at a distance between 4.1 (closer than Jupiter) and 2200 AU (70 times farther from the Sun than Neptune). The following is a list of TNOs with the largest aphelion in descending order. {{Bar graph | title = Approximate number of minor planets | float = right | bar_width = 20 | width_units = em | data_max = 30 | label_type = Aphelion

Buie |date = 2007-11-08 |title = Orbit Fit and Astrometric record for 04VN112 |publisher = SwRI (Space Science Department) |url = http://www.boulder.swri.edu/~buie/kbo/astrom/04VN112.html |accessdate = 2008-07-17 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100818145946/http://www.boulder.swri.edu/~buie/kbo/astrom/04VN112.html |archivedate = 2010-08-18 |df = }} {{cite web |title=JPL Small-Body Database Browser: (2004 VN112) |url=http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/sbdb.cgi?sstr=2004VN112 |accessdate=2011-05-20}} }} == External links == * [https://www.sciencenews.org/article/distant-planet-may-lurk-far-beyond-neptune A distant planet may lurk far beyond Neptune] * [http://www.space.com/28284-planet-x-worlds-beyond-pluto.html Mysterious Planet X May Really Lurk Undiscovered in Our Solar System] [[Category:Lists of Solar System objects|Aphelion]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Tuber'' (fungus) species}} This is a list of the species in the fungal genus ''[[Tuber (fungus)|Tuber]]''.
==Key== {| class="wikitable" style="width: 100%;" |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"| Name |The [[binomial name]] of the ''Tuber'' species. |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"| Authority |The [[Author citation (botany)|author citation]]—the person who first [[species description|described]] the species using an available scientific name, eventually combined with the one who placed it in ''Tuber'', and using standardized abbreviations. |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"|Year |The year in which the species was named, or transferred to the genus ''Tuber''. Where the actual year of publication (as defined for the purpose of [[Principle of Priority|priority]]) differs from the date given in the material, the latter date is given in quotes. |- ! style="text-align:left;" scope="row"|Distribution |The distribution of the species. |}

revision.text:
[[File:NASA's Hubble Reveals Rogue Planetary Orbit For Fomalhaut B.jpg|thumb|280px|Exoplanet [[Fomalhaut b]] (Dagon), 25 light-years away, with its parent star [[Fomalhaut]] blacked out, as pictured by [[Hubble Space Telescope|Hubble]] in 2012.{{cite web| url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hubble/science/rogue-fomalhaut.html| title=NASA's Hubble Reveals Rogue Planetary Orbit For Fomalhaut| date=2013-08-01| publisher=NASA| first1=J. D.| last1=Harrington| first2=Ray| last2=Villard| accessdate=2015-09-18| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151106185243/http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/hubble/science/rogue-fomalhaut.html| archivedate=2015-11-06| df=}}]] [[File:Distances to nearest confirmed exoplanets in light years.png|thumb|450px|Distribution of nearest exoplanets]] There are {{Extrasolar planet counts|planet_count}} known [[exoplanet]]s, or planets outside our [[Solar System|solar system]] that orbit a star, as of {{Extrasolar planet counts|asof|mdy}}; only a small fraction of these are located in the vicinity of the Solar System.{{cite web |title=Interactive Extra-solar Planets Catalog |website=[[The Extrasolar Planets Encyclopaedia]] |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog.php |last=Schneider |first=Jean |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |accessdate=2018-03-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/65IpZZPDT?url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog.php |archivedate=2012-02-08 |df= }} Within {{convert|10|pc|ly|lk=on|1|abbr=off}}, there are 56 exoplanets listed as confirmed by the [[NASA Exoplanet Archive]].{{ref label|A|a|none}} Among the over 400 known stars within 10 parsecs,{{ref label|B|b|none}}{{cite web |url=http://www.solstation.com/stars/pc10.htm |title=Stars within 10 parsecs |publisher=Solstation.com |date=2014-04-25 |accessdate=2018-03-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171026183135/http://www.solstation.com/stars/pc10.htm |archivedate=2017-10-26 |df= }} 26 have been confirmed to have planetary systems; 51 stars in this range are visible to the naked eye,{{ref label|C|c|none}}{{cite web |url=http://www.atlasoftheuniverse.com/50lys.html |title=Stars within 50 light years |publisher=An Atlas of the Universe |first=Richard |last=Powell |date=2006 |accessdate=2014-05-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140627140437/http://www.atlasoftheuniverse.com/50lys.html |archivedate=2014-06-27 |df= }} eight of which have planetary systems. The first report of an exoplanet within this range was in 1998 for a planet orbiting around [[Gliese 876]] (15.3 light-years (ly) away), and the latest as of 2017 is one around [[Ross 128]] (11 ly). The closest exoplanet found is [[Proxima Centauri b]], which was confirmed in 2016 to orbit [[Proxima Centauri]], the closest star to our Solar System (4.25 ly). [[HD 219134]] (21.6 ly) has six exoplanets, the highest number discovered for any star within this range. A planet around [[Fomalhaut]] (25 ly) was, in 2008, the first planet to be [[methods of detecting exoplanets#Direct imaging|directly imaged]].{{cite web| url=http://earthsky.org/brightest-stars/solitary-fomalhaut-guards-the-southern-sky| title=Fomalhaut had first visible exoplanet| first1=Larry| last1=Sessions| first2=Deborah| last2=Byrd| publisher=Earthsky.org| date=2017-09-22| accessdate=2018-03-15| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180326230515/http://earthsky.org/brightest-stars/solitary-fomalhaut-guards-the-southern-sky| archivedate=2018-03-26| df=}} Most known nearby exoplanets orbit close to their star and have highly [[Orbital eccentricity|eccentric orbits]]. A majority are significantly larger than Earth, but a few have similar masses, including two planets (around [[YZ Ceti]], 12 ly) which may be less massive than Earth. Several confirmed exoplanets are hypothesized to be [[List of potentially habitable exoplanets|potentially habitable]], with Proxima Centauri b and three around [[Gliese 667 C]] (23.6 ly) considered the most likely candidates. The [[International Astronomical Union]] took a public survey in 2015 about renaming some known extrasolar bodies, including the planets around [[Epsilon Eridani]] (10.5 ly) and Fomalhaut.{{ref label|D|d|none}}{{cite press release | url = https://www.iau.org/news/pressreleases/detail/iau1514/ | publisher = International Astronomical Union | title = Final Results of NameExoWorlds Public Vote Released | date = 2015-12-15 | accessdate = 2018-03-17 | deadurl = no | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20180515174310/https://www.iau.org/news/pressreleases/detail/iau1514/ | archivedate = 2018-05-15 | df = }} ==Exoplanets within 10 parsecs== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="float:left; font-size: small; text-align: center;" |+ Key to colors |- | style="background:#CEF2E0; width:20px;"| ° | align=left|[[Mercury (planet)|Mercury]], [[Earth]] and [[Jupiter]] (for comparison purposes) |- | style="background:#ffffb0; width:20px;"| # |align=left|Confirmed [[List of multiplanetary systems|multiplanetary systems]] |- | style="background:#BCD4E6;" width:20px;"| ↑ |align=left|Exoplanets believed to be [[List of potentially habitable exoplanets|potentially habitable]] |} {| class="wikitable sortable" style="margin:auto; text-align:center; display:inline-block; border-width:0;" |+ style="background:white" | Exoplanets listed as confirmed in the [[NASA Exoplanet Archive]]{{cite web|url=https://exoplanetarchive.ipac.caltech.edu/cgi-bin/TblView/nph-tblView?app=ExoTbls&config=planets |title=NASA Exoplanet Archive—Confirmed Planets |website=NASA Exoplanet Science Institute|publisher=California Institute of Technology |date= |accessdate=2018-03-22}} |- ! colspan = "4"| [[Star|Host star system]] ! scope="col" colspan = "8" | [[Exoplanet|Companion exoplanet]] (in order from star) ! scope="col" class="unsortable" rowspan="2" style="width:50px"| Notes and additional planetary observations |- ! scope="col" |Name ! scope="col" |[[Cosmic distance ladder|Distance]]

According to the [[International Astronomical Union]], an exoplanet should be considered confirmed if it has not been disputed for five years after its discovery.{{cite web |url=http://www.techtimes.com/articles/77119/20150818/want-to-name-an-exoplanet-heres-your-chance.htm |first=Rhodi |last=Lee |title=Want To Name An Exoplanet? Here's Your Chance |publisher=Tech Times |date=2015-09-18 |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150907115335/http://www.techtimes.com/articles/77119/20150818/want-to-name-an-exoplanet-heres-your-chance.htm |archivedate=2015-09-07 |df= }} There have been examples where the existence of exoplanets has been proposed, but even after follow-up studies their existence is still considered doubtful by some astronomers. Such cases include: [[Alpha Centauri]] (4.36 ly, two in 2012{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/alf_cen_b_b |title=alf Cen B b |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |date=2011-05-27 |accessdate=2014-05-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140625075606/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/alf_cen_b_b/ |archivedate=2014-06-25 |df= }} and 2013{{cite web |url=http://www.drewexmachina.com/2015/03/28/has-another-planet-been-found-orbiting-alpha-centauri-b/ |title=Has Another Planet Been Found Orbiting Alpha Centauri B? |first=Andrew |last=LePage |publisher=Drew Ex Machina |date=2015-03-28 |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929103322/http://www.drewexmachina.com/2015/03/28/has-another-planet-been-found-orbiting-alpha-centauri-b/ |archivedate=2015-09-29 |df= }}), [[Lalande 21185]] (8.31 ly, in 2017{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/lalande_21185_b/ |title=Lalande 21185 b |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |date=2017-02-14 |accessdate=2018-03-23 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324162533/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/lalande_21185_b/ |archivedate=2018-03-24 |df= }}), [[Groombridge 34 A|Groombridge 34]] (11.7 ly, two in 2014{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_15_a_b |title=GJ 15 A b |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |accessdate=2015-01-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807042943/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_15_a_b/ |archivedate=2016-08-07 |df= }} and 2017{{cite journal|doi=10.1051/0004-6361/201731442|title=The CARMENES search for exoplanets around M dwarfs|journal=Astronomy & Astrophysics|volume=609|issue=117|pages=A117|year=2018| last1=Trifonov|first1=T|last2=Kürster|first2=M|last3=Zechmeister|first3=M|last4=Tal-Or|first4=L|last5=Caballero|first5=J. A|display-authors=3|arxiv=1710.01595|bibcode=2018A&A...609A.117T}}), [[Epsilon Indi]] (11.8 ly, in 2018{{cite web | url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/eps_ind_a_b/ | title=eps Ind A b | website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia | publisher=Exoplanet.eu | date=2018-03-29 | accessdate=2018-05-11 | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180511150013/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/eps_ind_a_b/ | archivedate=2018-05-11 | df= }}), [[LHS 288]] (15.6 ly, in 2007{{cite journal| doi=10.1086/599044| title=A Search for Astrometric Companions to Stars in the Southern Hemisphere| journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific| volume=121| issue=878| page=365| year=2009| last1=Bartlett| first1=Jennifer L| last2=Ianna| first2=Philip A| last3=Begam| first3=Michael C| bibcode=2009PASP..121..365B}}), [[40 Eridani]] (16.3 ly, in 2018{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/hd_26965_b/ |title=HD 26965 b |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |date=2018-01-15 |accessdate=2018-03-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180324162430/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/hd_26965_b/ |archivedate=2018-03-24 |df= }}), [[Gliese 682]] (16.6 ly, two in 2014{{cite web |url=http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog |title=The Habitable Exoplanets Catalog |website=Planetary Habitability Laboratory |publisher=[[University of Puerto Rico]] in Arecibo |date=2015-09-01 |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160109001847/http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog |archivedate=2016-01-09 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_682_b/ |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |title=GJ 682 b |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |accessdate=2015-03-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402132202/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_682_b/ |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_682_c/ |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |title=GJ 682 c |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |accessdate=2015-03-30 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150402093100/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_682_c/ |archivedate=2015-04-02 |df= }}), and [[Gliese 229]] (18.8 ly, in 2014{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_229_b/ |title=GJ 229 b |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |date=2014-05-25 |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160807014049/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/gj_229_b/ |archivedate=2016-08-07 |df= }}). There are also some instances where proposed exoplanets were later disproved by subsequent studies, such as candidates around [[Teegarden's star]] (12.6 ly),{{cite journal| journal=[[Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society]]| title=ROPS: A New Search for Habitable Earths in the Southern Sky| last1=Barnes |first1=J.R.|first2=J. S. |last2=Jenkins|first3=H. R. A. |last3=Jones|first4=P. |last4=Rojo|display-authors=3|date=July 2012| volume=424| issue=1 | pages=591–604| doi=10.1111/j.1365-2966.2012.21236.x | bibcode=2012MNRAS.424..591B | arxiv = 1204.6283}} [[Van Maanen 2]] (13.9 ly),{{cite journal | last1=Farihi | first1=J. | last2=Becklin | first2=E. E. | last3=Macintosh | first3=B. A. | title=Mid-Infrared Observations of van Maanen 2: No Substellar Companion | journal=Astrophysical Journal Letters |date=June 2004 | volume=608 | issue=2 | pages=L109–L112 | doi=10.1086/422502 | bibcode=2004ApJ...608L.109F | arxiv=astro-ph/0405245 }} [[Groombridge 1618]] (15.9 ly),{{cite journal | display-authors=3 | title=Constraints on Long-period Planets from an L'- and M-band Survey of Nearby Sun-like Stars: Observations | last1=Heinze | first1=A. N. | last2=Hinz | first2=Philip M. | last3=Sivanandam | first3=Suresh | last4=Kenworthy | first4=Matthew | last5=Meyer | first5=Michael | last6=Miller | first6=Douglas | journal=The Astrophysical Journal | volume=714 | issue=2 | pages=1551–1569 |date=May 2010 | doi=10.1088/0004-637X/714/2/1551 | bibcode=2010ApJ...714.1551H |arxiv = 1003.5340 }} and [[VB 10]] (18.7 ly).{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/vb_10_b/ |title=VB 10 b |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150929194632/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/vb_10_b/ |archivedate=2015-09-29 |df= }} The Working Group on Extrasolar Planets of the International Astronomical Union adopted in 2003 a working definition on the upper limit for what constitutes a planet: not being massive enough to sustain thermonuclear fusion of [[deuterium]]. Some studies have calculated this to be somewhere around 13 times the [[Mass of Jupiter#Mass|mass of Jupiter]], and therefore objects more massive than this are usually classified as [[brown dwarf]]s.{{cite journal|display-authors=3|last1=Boss|first1=Alan P.|last2=Butler|first2=R. Paul|last3=Hubbard|first3=William B.|last4=Ianna|first4=Philip A.|last5=Kürster|first5=Martin |title=Working Group on Extrasolar Planets|journal=Proceedings of the International Astronomical Union |volume=1|issue=T26A|date=2007|page=183|doi=10.1017/S1743921306004509|bibcode = 2007IAUTA..26..183B}} Some proposed candidate exoplanets were later shown to be massive enough to fall above the threshold, and are likely brown dwarfs, as was the case for: [[SCR 1845-6357#SCR 1845-6357 B|SCR 1845-6357 B]] (12.6 ly),{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/scr_1845_b/ |title=SCR 1845 b |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |date=2012-04-13 |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151001143712/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/scr_1845_b/ |archivedate=2015-10-01 |df= }} [[SDSS J1416+1348|SDSS J1416+1348 B]] (29.7 ly),{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/sdss_141624_b/ |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |title=SDSS 141624 b |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |date=2010-01-18 |accessdate=2014-05-20 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223211309/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/sdss_141624_b/ |archivedate=2014-02-23 |df= }} and [[WISE 1217+1626|WISE 1217+1626 B]] (30 ly).{{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/wise_1217+16_a_b/ |website=The Extrasolar Planet Encyclopaedia |title=WISE 1217+16A b |publisher=Exoplanet.eu |accessdate=2014-05-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170612172859/http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/wise_1217%2B16_a_b/ |archivedate=2017-06-12 |df= }} Excluded from the current list are known examples of potential free-floating [[sub-brown dwarf]]s, or "[[rogue planet]]s", which are bodies that are too small to undergo fusion yet they do not revolve around a star. Known such examples include: [[WISE 0855–0714]] (7.3 ly),{{cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/jpl/wise/spitzer-coldest-brown-dwarf-20140425/ |title=NASA's Spitzer and WISE Telescopes Find Close, Cold Neighbor of Sun |work=NASA |first1=Whitney |last1=Clavin |first2=J. D. |last2=Harrington |date=2014-04-25 |accessdate=2015-09-17 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140426004939/http://www.nasa.gov/jpl/wise/spitzer-coldest-brown-dwarf-20140425 |archivedate=2014-04-26 |df= }} [[UGPS 0722-05]], (13 ly){{cite journal |last1=Lucas |first1=P. W. |last2=Tinney | first2=C. G. |last3=Burningham | first3=B. |last4=Leggett | first4=S. K. |title=The discovery of a very cool, very nearby brown dwarf in the Galactic plane |date=2010 |journal=Monthly Notices of the Royal Astronomical Society |volume=408 | issue=1 | pages=L56–L60 |display-authors=3 |arxiv=1004.0317 |doi=10.1111/j.1745-3933.2010.00927.x |bibcode=2010MNRAS.408L..56L}} [[WISE 1541−2250]] (18.6 ly),{{cite journal |display-authors=3 |last=Cushing |first=Michael C. |title=The Discovery of Y Dwarfs using Data from the Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer (WISE) |date=2011 |arxiv=1108.4678 |doi=10.1088/0004-637X/743/1/50 |bibcode=2011ApJ...743...50C|journal=The Astrophysical Journal |volume= 743 |page=50 |number =1 |last2=Kirkpatrick |first2=J. {{sort| 0.3 |> 0.20 }} | style="text-align:center;"|14 |} {{Col-break}} {| class="sortable wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |+ Exoplanets by discovery year ! scope="col" |Year ! scope="col" |№ |- !1998 | 1 |- !2000 | 2 |- !2005 | 2 |- !2006 | 1 |- !2007 | 3 |- !2008 | 2 |- !2009 | 6 |- !2010 | 3 |- !2011 | 5 |- !2013 | 3 |- !2014 | 3 |- !2015 | 9 |- !2016 | 1 |- !2017 | 15 |- !2018 | 3 |} {{col-end}} == See also == {{Div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[List of nearest stars and brown dwarfs]] * [[List of nearest bright stars]] * [[List of nearest terrestrial exoplanet candidates]] * [[List of nearest free floating planetary mass objects]] * [[List of exoplanets (full)]] * [[Lists of planets]] * [[List of planet types]] * [[List of potentially habitable exoplanets]] {{div col end}} ==Notes== {{ordered list|type=a | item1_value = 1 | 1 = {{note label|A|a|none}} Listed values are primarily taken from ''[[NASA Exoplanet Archive]]'', but other databases include a few additional exoplanet entries tagged as "Confirmed" that are have yet to be compiled into the NASA archive. Such databases include: :: {{cite web |url=http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/ | title = Exoplanet Catalog | website =[[The Extrasolar Planets Encyclopaedia]] | at=[http://exoplanet.eu/catalog/all_fields/ Full table]}} :: {{cite web |url=http://exoplanets.org/table/ |title=Exoplanets Data Explorer | website = Exoplanet Orbit Database | publisher = California Planet Survey | at=Click the "+" button to visualize additional parameters}} :: {{cite web |url=http://www.openexoplanetcatalogue.com/systems/ |title=Open Exoplanet Catalogue |at=Click the "Show options" to visualize additional parameters}} | item2_value = 2 | 2 = {{note label|B|b|none}} For reference, the 104th closest known star system in November 2016 was [[82 Eridani]] (19.7 ly).{{cite web | url=http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/astro/nearstar.html | first=Robert | last=Johnston | date=2014-11-02 | title=List of Nearby Stars: To 21 light years | accessdate=2015-09-17 | publisher=Johnstonsarchive.net | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151016062030/http://www.johnstonsarchive.net/astro/nearstar.html | archivedate=2015-10-16 | df= }} | item3_value = 3 | 3 = {{note label|C|c|none}} According to the [[Bortle scale]], an astronomical object is visible to the naked eye under "typical" dark-sky conditions in a rural area if it has an [[apparent magnitude]] smaller than +6.5. To the unaided eye, the limiting magnitude is +7.6 to +8.0 under "excellent" dark-sky conditions (with effort).{{cite journal |journal= Sky & Telescope |date = 2001|title = Light Pollution And Astronomy: The Bortle Dark-Sky Scale |first = John E. |last= Bortle|url = http://www.skyandtelescope.com/resources/darksky/3304011.html|accessdate = 2014-05-20}} | item4_value = 4 | 4 = {{note label|D|d|none}} The star [[Epsilon Eridani]] was named ''Ran'' (after [[Rán]], the Norse goddess of the sea), and the planet [[Epsilon Eridani b]] was named ''AEgir'' (after [[Ægir]], Rán's husband),{{cite web |url=http://nameexoworlds.iau.org/systems/105 |title=epsilon Eridani |website=NameExoWorlds |publisher=International Astronomical Union |date= |accessdate=2018-05-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180215023352/http://nameexoworlds.iau.org/systems/105 |archivedate=2018-02-15 |df= }} while the planet [[Fomalhaut b]] was named ''Dagon'' (after [[Dagon]], an ancient Syrian “fish god”{{cite web |url=http://nameexoworlds.iau.org/systems/103 |title=Fomalhaut (alpha Piscis Austrini) |website=Nameexoworlds |publisher=International Astronomical Union |date= |accessdate=2018-05-14 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170430100341/http://nameexoworlds.iau.org/systems/103 |archivedate=2017-04-30 |df= }}). | item5_value = 5 | 5 = {{note label|E|e|none}} [[Exoplanet naming convention]] assigns uncapitalized letters starting from ''b'' to each planet based on chronological order of their initial report, and in increasing order of distance from the parent star for planets reported at the same time. Omitted letters signify planets that have yet to be confirmed, or planets that have been retracted altogether. | item6_value = 6 | 6 = {{note label|F|f|none}} Most reported exoplanet masses have very large error margins (typically, between 10% and 30%). The mass of an exoplanet has generally been inferred from measurements on changes in the [[radial velocity]] of the host star, but this kind of measurement only allows for an estimate on the exoplanet's orbital parameters, but not on their [[orbital inclination]] (''i''). As such, most exoplanets only have an estimated [[minimum mass]] (Mreal*sin(''i'')), where their [[true mass]]es are statistically expected to come close to this minimum, with only about 13% chance for the mass of an exoplanet to be more than double its minimum mass.{{Cite journal| first=Andrew |last=Cumming|date=2008|title=The Keck Planet Search: Detectability and the Minimum Mass and Orbital Period Distribution of Extrasolar Planets|journal=Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific|volume=120| issue=867|pages=531–554| arxiv=0803.3357|doi=10.1086/588487| bibcode=2008PASP..120..531C| first2=R. Paul |last2=Butler| first3=Geoffrey W.|last3=Marcy| last4=Vogt| first4=Steven S.| last5=Wright| first5=Jason T.| last6=Fischer| first6=Debra A.| authorlink3=Debra Fischer | display-authors=3|year=2008}} }} ==References== {{reflist|colwidth=40em|3}} == External links == * {{cite web|url=http://www.planetary.org/explore/space-topics/exoplanets/ |title=Extrasolar Planets |website = [[The Planetary Society]] |publisher=Planetary.org |date= }} * {{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/news/space_time/extrasolar_planets/ | title=Extrasolar Planets News | publisher = [[Science Daily]]}} * {{cite web|url=https://exoplanets.nasa.gov/ |title=Exoplanet Exploration: Planets Beyond our Solar System | website = Exoplanet Exploration Program and [[Jet Propulsion Laboratory]] |publisher=NASA |date=2015-12-16 }} * {{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/space/universe/sights/extrasolar_planets |title=Universe - Exoplanets (pictures, video, facts & news) |publisher=BBC |date= |access-date=2018-03-23 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180213200942/http://www.bbc.co.uk/science/space/universe/sights/extrasolar_planets |archive-date=2018-02-13 |dead-url=yes |df= }} * {{cite web|url=http://phl.upr.edu/projects/habitable-exoplanets-catalog/data/database |title=PHL's Exoplanets Catalog |website=Planetary Habitability Laboratory | publisher = UPR Arecibo |date=2018-03-02 }} * {{cite web|author=Onsi Fakhouri |url=http://exoplanets.org/ |title=Exoplanet Orbit Database |website=[[Exoplanet Data Explorer]] |publisher=Exoplanets.org |date= }} {{Exoplanet}} {{Exoplanet search projects}} {{featured list}} [[Category:Lists of stars]] [[Category:Planetary systems|*]] [[Category:Lists of exoplanets|Nearest]]

In electrical power engineering, '''fault ride through''' ('''FRT'''), sometimes '''under-voltage ride through''' ('''UVRT'''), or '''low voltage ride through''' ('''LVRT'''),<ref>[http://std.iec.ch/terms/terms.nsf/0/DB2CF1567097E866C1257E29002C35B3?OpenDocument IEC Glossary: UVRT]</ref> is the capability of electric generators to stay connected in short periods of lower [[Electric power transmission|electric network]] [[voltage]] (cf. [[voltage dip]]). It is needed at distribution level ([[wind turbine|wind parks]], [[photovoltaics|PV systems]], distributed [[cogeneration]], etc.) to prevent a short circuit at HV or EHV level from causing a widespread loss of generation. Similar requirements for critical loads such as computer systems<ref>http://www.powerqualityworld.com/2011/04/cbema-curve-power-quality-standard.html CBEMA Curve – The Power Acceptability Curve for Computer Business Equipment, 2011-04-03</ref> and industrial processes are often handled through the use of an [[uninterruptible power supply]] (UPS) or capacitor bank to supply make-up power during these events.
==General concept== Many generator designs use electric current flowing through windings to produce the magnetic field on which the motor or generator operates. This is in contrast to designs that use [[permanent magnet]]s to generate this field instead. Such devices may have a minimum working voltage, below which the device does not work correctly, or does so at greatly reduced efficiency. Some will disconnect themselves from the circuit when these conditions apply. The effect is more pronounced in [[Doubly fed electric machine|doubly-fed induction generators]] (DFIG), which have two sets of powered magnetic windings, than in [[Squirrel-cage rotor|squirrel-cage induction generators]] which have only one. [[Synchronous generator]]s may slip and become unstable, if the voltage of the stator winding goes below a certain threshold.
==Risk of chain reaction== In a grid containing many distributed generators subject to disconnection at under voltage, it is possible to cause a [[chain reaction]] that takes other generators offline as well. This can occur in the event of a [[Power dips|voltage dip]] that causes one of the generators to disconnect from the grid. As voltage dips are often caused by too little generation for the load in a distribution grid, removing generation can cause the voltage to drop further. This may bring the voltage down enough to cause another generator to trip, lower the voltage even further, and may cause a [[cascading failure]].
==Ride through systems== Modern large-scale wind turbines, typically 1 MW and larger, are normally required to include systems that allow them to operate through such an event, and thereby “ride through” the voltage dip. Similar requirements are now becoming common on large [[solar power]] installations that likewise might cause instability in the event of a widespread disconnection of generating units. Depending on the application the device may, during and after the dip, be required to:
* disconnect and stay disconnected until manually ordered to reconnect * disconnect temporarily from the grid, but reconnect and continue operation after the dip * stay operational and not disconnect from the grid * stay connected and support the grid with [[reactive power]] (defined as the reactive current of the positive sequence of the fundamental)<ref name="Akagi_2007">{{cite book |title = Instantaneous power theory and applications to power conditioning |last1 = Akagi |first1 = H. |author2=Edson Hirokazu Watanabe |author3=Mauricio Aredes |year=2007 |publisher=[[John Wiley & Sons]] |isbn=978-0-470-10761-4 |series=IEEE Press Series of Power Engineering |page=137 }}</ref>
==Standards== A variety of standards exist and generally vary across jurisdictions. Examples of the such grid codes are the German BDEW grid code<ref>[http://www.bdew.de/internet.nsf/id/A2A0475F2FAE8F44C12578300047C92F/$file/BDEW_RL_EA-am-MS-Netz_engl.pdf BDEW Medium Voltage Guideline] retrieved on 9 November 2008</ref> and its supplements 2,<ref>[http://www.bdew.de/internet.nsf/id/A2A0475F2FAE8F44C12578300047C92F/$file/2010-07_BDEW_Ergänzung-zu-MS-Richtlinie_englisch.pdf BDEW MV Guideline 2nd Supplement] retrieved in 07/2010</ref> 3,<ref>[http://www.bdew.de/internet.nsf/id/A2A0475F2FAE8F44C12578300047C92F/$file/2011-02_BDEW_Ergänzung-zu-MS-Richtlinie_end-englisch.pdf BDEW MV Guideline 3rd Supplement] retrieved in 02/2011</ref> and 4<ref>[https://www.bdew.de/internet.nsf/id/A2A0475F2FAE8F44C12578300047C92F/$file/4.%20Erg%C3%A4nzung%20BDEW-MSR%20final_englisch.pdf BDEW MV Guideline 4th Supplement] retrieved in 12/2015</ref> as well as the National Grid Code in UK.<ref>[http://www.nationalgrid.com/uk/Electricity/Codes/gridcode/gridcodedocs/ National Grid Code] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100214010602/http://www.nationalgrid.com/uk/Electricity/Codes/gridcode/gridcodedocs |date=2010-02-14 }} retrieved on 9 2008-11-9</ref>
==Testing== For wind turbines, the FRT testing is described in the standard IEC 61400-21 (2nd edition August 2008). More detailed testing procedures are stated in the German guideline FGW TR3 (Rev. 22). Testing of devices with less than 16 Amp rated current is described in the EMC standard [[International Electrotechnical Commission|IEC]] 61000-4-11 and for higher current devices in IEC 61000-4-34.

Sacred grove of ancient Pisaureum, '''Lucus Pisaurensis''' is a sacerdotal [[lucus]] lying just outside the coastal ''comune'' of [[Pesaro]], Italy between the Colle della Salute (Hill of Salus) and the Collina (Hillside of the Springs of Beatitude) in Santa Veneranda.<ref>Il Pignocco ''About Us'' http://www.ilpignocco.it/en/about-us/lucus-pisaurensis/</ref> Santa Veneranda is a hamlet in the [[Pesaro e Urbino]] Province of [[Marche]], Italy, a pre-''Imperium Romanum'' region of the Latin [[Sabini]], [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Umbrian]] and [[Latins (Italic tribe)|Estrucan]] tribes.
==History of Discovery==
''Pisaurensia Marmora'', ("Marble of Pesaro-Umbria"), a manuscript written by 18th Century Italian aristocrat Annibale degli Abbati Olivieri Giordani, was published in 1738.<ref>''Ancient Art and Its Remains'', by Karl Otfried Müller, publ. 1847 https://books.google.com/books?id=yI8ZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA248</ref> In the preface, Olivieri reports having discovered, in the prior year, a sacred grove on his estate in a farm field by the little ''Chiostro di Santo Gaetano dei Conti.''<ref>Saints of the Catholic Church, ''Santo Gaetano'' http://catholicsaints.info/tag/born-in-1480/</ref> He calls the site ''Lucus Pisaurensis'' (Sacred Grove of Pesaro) and provides a brief description of his findings. Olivieri further states that he plans to publish a future manuscript entitled ''De Luco Sacred Veterum Pisaurensium'' ("The Sacred Grove of Ancient Pisaurensis"), once excavations are completed. This work however, was never published and interest in the ''lucus'' disappeared after Oliviera's passing.
'''21st Century'''
During excavations in the 21st century, the grove was rediscovered<ref>M. Cardone, "New Oliveriani documents on Lucus Pisaurensis", in Studia Oliveriana Series III, III-IV, Pesaro 2003-2004</ref> and archaeological interest in the site renewed.<ref>Maria Teresa Di Luca Gabriele Baldelli, Pier Luigi Dall'Aglio, ''The Lucus Pisaurensis'' (Pesaro and Archaeology. Thematic Papers), Municipality of Pesaro, 2004; Gabriele Stroppa, "First to Pisauro Tombstone'', New Research in Fragments, n. 12, Pesaro 2008; "The Impact of Imperium Romanum on Luci (Sacred Glades, Clearings and Groves) in Italy", by L. Bouke van der Meer, BABESCH 90, 2015</ref>
==The Findings==
Oliveri unearthed in his field, near the ancient ''fontanine'' by the ''Chiostro di Santo Gaetano dei Conti'',<ref>Saints of the Catholic Church, ''Saint Gaetano'' http://catholicsaints.info/tag/born-in-1480/</ref> 13 [[Votive Stones of Pesaro|votive stones]]<ref>Oliveriano Archaeological Museum http://www.euromuse.net/en/museums/museum/view-m/museo-archeologico-oliveriano</ref> or ''cippi'',<ref>''Cippi of Luci'' https://www.academia.edu/15804636/The_impact_of_Rome_on_luci_sacred_glades_clearings_and_groves_in_Italy_BABESCH_90_2015_99-107</ref> carved of sandstone with Sabine inscriptions in Umbrian-Estrucan; a number of terracotta and sandstone artifacts; clay & copper coin;<ref>Il Pignocco, ''Lucus'' http://www.ilpignocco.it/en/about-us/lucus-pisaurensis/</ref> and a small ''semo'' replica in bronze inscribed ''Libra''.<ref>''Voti of Luci'' https://www.academia.edu/15804636/The_impact_of_Rome_on_luci_sacred_glades_clearings_and_groves_in_Italy_BABESCH_90_2015_99-107</ref> The votives were inscribed with names of various Sabini-Estrucan ''semones'': [[Salus|Salute]], [[Fides (deity)|Fide]], [[Lucina (goddess)|Lucina]], [[Marica (mythology)|Marica]], [[Feronia (Etruria)|Feronia]], [[Juno (mythology)|Juno Regina]]; as well as the later Roman Gods: [[Janus|Iunos]], Apolenei, Diana, Mater Matuta.
In addition to the found votives, coin and idol, a terracotta borderline marker was unearthed, inscribed: " ''δ Δ δ luci coiirii CI LX'' ". ''Luci Coiiri'' means 'Coerian Grove' and the Roman numerals are taken to reference land measurements.<ref>''Cippi of Luci'', by L. Bouke van der Meer, BABESCH 90, 2015, ppg 103-104, ref. Gen. 2:21 מִצַּלְעֹתָ֔יו https://www.academia.edu/15804636/The_impact_of_Rome_on_luci_sacred_glades_clearings_and_groves_in_Italy_BABESCH_90_2015_99-107</ref>
Olivieri found numerous other artifacts on his estate, all of which are housed in the [[Biblioteca Oliveriana, Pesaro|Biblioteca Oliveriana]], a Museum and Library in Pesaro that he founded. Among these many findings are bronze and clay coinage, carved sandstone stela from 7th C. B.C. depicting naumachia (mock naval battles), the famed bronze Tabula Fabrorum<ref>''La Tabula Fabrorum'' http://www.fondazione.scavolini.com/restauri-tabula-fabrorum.asp?m2=7</ref> with the relief of Etruscan goddess [[Minerva]] ([[Pallas Athena]]).
The ''fontanine'', or little fountains of stone, by groves near the ''Chiostro'' where many of the votives are discoveried, give archaeologists reason to connect the ''lucus'' to a cult of water<ref>Strong's Hebrew Concordance 4325, Gen. 1:6 http://biblehub.com/hebrew/4325.htm</ref> goddesses.<ref>Il Pignocco, ''Chapel'' http://www.ilpignocco.it/en/about-us/history/</ref> Latin meaning of the word ''fontanine''<ref>Online Etymology Dictionary http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=fountain</ref> is 'spring waters' as referenced by Decimus Iūnius Iuvenālis, a Silver Age Roman poet, (55 - c. 138 CE), ''Quaesitum ad fontem solos deducere verpus'', "To guide only the ''condūcēbāmus'' to the fountain that they seek."<ref>''Ancient Rome, Juvenal'' http://www.ancient-literature.com/rome_juvenal.html</ref>
'''Evolution of Votives'''
It is of interest to note that over the millennia, as the original purpose of ''luci'' became lost, votive stones, [[Cippi of Melqart|cippi]] and [[Stele|stelae]] translated to become [[Headstone|grave markers]] and [[Samadhi (shrine)|tombs]].<ref>''The Stelae of Ancient Egypt'' http://m.touregypt.net/featurestories/stela.htm</ref>
==Elements of Sacred Groves (''Luci'')==
Ceremonies in ''luci'' were centered around classic elements of a spring and a sylvan wood or coppice.<ref>''Trees, Forests And Sacred Groves'', by Sarah A. Laird http://www.agroforestry.net/the-overstory/74-overstory-195-trees-forests-and-sacred-groves</ref> Trees with certain desired qualities of a mystical nature and waters of a certain [[Holy well|mineral purity]] were essential to the creating of a Sacred Grove.<ref>''Minoan Life in Bronze Age Crete'', by Rodney Castleden, Routledge, 1990, pg 138, ''priestés and sacred olive trees'' https://books.google.com/books?id=esSIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PT117&lpg=PT117&dq=sacred+trees+bronze+age&source=bl&ots=8pVNBb-av-&sig=8jE3yd8Gh95EW1lMk0ObOy87wpk&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwisuY2t3dLPAhWF4CYKHQhODKMQ6AEIHDAA#v=onepage&q=sacred%20trees%20bronze%20age&f=false</ref>
One of these trees is the [[Laurus nobilis]] (''lat.'' Laures, ''gr.'' Dáphnē Δάφνη), a [[Mediterranean race|Mediterranean]] tree native to the Greek and Roman territories of the early [[List of ancient peoples of Italy|Italics]], [[Illyrians]] and [[Iberians]]. The leaves, roots, berries and bark of the [[Bay leaf|bay laurel]] contain volatile oils, [[malabathrum]],<ref>''Article on Properties of the Lauraceae, C. tamala'' http://www.herbwisdom.com/herb-bay.html</ref> which stimulate sense glands of the nose, and were the basis<ref>English Oxford Dictionary, ''basis (synonym)'' starting point https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/thesaurus/basis</ref> of these rituals. ''{See Wikipedia article on [[Common sense]], section on Aristotelian common sense}''
Earliest ceremonies<ref>''Report of the Annual Meeting'', by British Association for the Advancement of Science, publ.1896, Vol. 66, pg 934, ''"Sacred Trees & Votive Stones in the Bronze Age"'' https://books.google.com/books?id=lOs4AAAAMAAJ&pg=PA934&lpg=PA934&dq=sacred+enclosures+sacred+tree+cult+bronze+age&source=bl&ots=oaDycdhKLb&sig=uEJWGp4wDOrZVFRmYBVH1H3IBJ4&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4x86629LPAhXFwj4KHUXKANwQ6AEIJjAD#v=onepage&q=sacred%20enclosures%20sacred%20tree%20cult%20bronze%20age&f=false</ref> of the [[Bronze Age|bronze-age]] were very naturalistic, ''πῖπτον'' <ref>Lexicon of Homeric Dialect, 1889 http://stephanus.tlg.uci.edu/cunliffe/#eid=3886&context=lsj</ref> in scope and were enacted within an atmosphere of laurel-enhanced [[mysticism]] in the minds of the ethnarches<ref>Oxford Dictionaries https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/ethnarch</ref> (founding tribal leaders) who performed these simple ceremonies<ref>Jeremiah 2:2 KJV ''espousals'' http://biblehub.com/kjv/jeremiah/2-2.htm</ref> with their semones<ref>''Indo-European Sacred Space: Vedic and Roman Cult'', by Roger Woodard, U. Ill. Press 2005, ppg 183-184, ''sacred seedings'' https://books.google.com/books?id=EB4fB0inNYEC&pg=PA182&lpg=PA182&dq=semones+gods&source=bl&ots=zl-o1oWKFj&sig=41hS60w7ZQSBiSNxEdStk0TUS4A&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiJ8qH0pNDPAhUJSiYKHUW4DVMQ6AEIOzAC#v=onepage&q=semones%20gods&f=false</ref> in the surroundings of their sacred groves.
The [[Carmen Arvale]] is a surviving Classical-Age ''Anticuus Latius<ref>WordSense Dictionary http://www.wordsense.eu/antiquus/</ref> vocare mei'' chant of ''di semones''<ref>''The Manners and Customs of the Ancient Egyptians'', by Sir John Gardner Wilkinson, 1847, Vol 4, pg 181, ''Indigetes'' https://books.google.com/books?id=Z3wOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA181&lpg=PA181&dq=semones+gods&source=bl&ots=Y85C-M9aI6&sig=GZgMpVlLQsA_Yl7NOR8_vTwNNiU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwigwqKFxNLPAhUB5SYKHRLzBngQ6AEISDAI#v=onepage&q=semones%20gods&f=false</ref> with the praepositus calling forth ''quod potentia'' of their guardian divinities and imploring them to ''limen sali, sta.''
'''An Allegorical Myth of "Luci"'''
Daphne, a naiad (nymph, a spirit of springs and sacred groves) is pursued by Apollo and when she entreaties, is allegorically turned to a [[Cinnamomum tamala|''laures'']] tree by her river god [[Ladon (mythology)|Ladon]].
==Etymologies==
'''Pisaureum''', original name of [[Pesaro]], from Pisaurus; ''gr.'' [ᵉ]Pì, by the side of '''+''' ''gr.'' sauria from ''sanskrt.'' s`aura, ☯ (symbol of dynamic union) ₊ sun's aura '''+''' ''lat.'' -ium or ''lat.'' -us, both from ''gr.'' -ion or -ia, a state, condition, or quality caused by activities such as those of a ritual<ref>History of Pesaro http://www.italythisway.com/places/articles/pesaro-history.php</ref><ref>http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=-y</ref>
'''Sacerdotal Lucus''', A Sacred Wood; '''Sacerdotal''' [sacer, ''lat.'' sacred '''+''' dotal, ''lat.'' giving], sacred giving or offering;<ref>Online Etymology Dictionary http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=sacerdotal</ref> '''Lucus''', ''lat.'', lux, light<ref>Latin Dictionary http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/resolveform?type=exact&lookup=lucus&lang=latin</ref>
'''Condūcēbāmus''', ''lat.''1st person imperfect,<ref>Latin Dictionary http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=conduco</ref> channel through, combine together, unite; gunas of Nature, of that which binds together<ref>American Vedic Studi. Institute https://vedanet.com/2012/06/13/the-three-gunas-how-to-balance-your-consciousness/</ref>
'''Coerian''', ''lat.'' cor, of the heart, of the soul; from ''gr.'' kardía καρδία,<ref>Latin Etymology Dictionary, [Definition II.b.] http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=cor</ref> from ''an. gr.'' kéar κῆρ, with all the heart; from ''PIE'' ḱḗr, fr. ''proto-PIE'' m'ḳerd, ''Sẇan'' cognate muč̣û`ed, of the breast<ref>https://en.m.wiktionary.org/wiki/κῆρ#</ref>
'''Collina di Calibano''', Hillside of Beātificus; '''Collina''' ''it.'', down hill;<ref>Dizionario Tolkien http://translation.babylon-software.com/italian/collina/</ref> '''Calibano''' ''gr.'' καλλίστη inner beauty, ''lat.'' Beātificus, blessedness, a state of holy bliss,<ref>Online Dictionary, Hebrew definition, ''beatific'' https://www.google.com/search?q=beatific&oq=beatific&aqs=chrome..69i57.1914j0j4&client=ms-android-verizon&sourceid=chrome-mobile&ie=UTF-8</ref> calque ''samadhi''<ref>A Tibetan Verb Lexicon, by Paul G. Hackett, Snow Lion Publ., 2003 https://books.google.com/books?id=CY0KGFUFpFsC&pg=PA59&lpg=PA59&dq=bliss+samadhi+lexicon&source=bl&ots=xARUcdffTv&sig=fkJR4kU-3eyfSsBamoqy15vYrjE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi1wMf6zMjPAhXJ6SYKHZY5BAgQ6AEIVTAJ#v=onepage&q=bliss%20samadhi%20lexicon&f=false</ref>
'''Colle della Salute''', Hill of Salus; '''Colle''' ''it.'', hill;<ref>Dizionario Tolkien http://translation.babylon-software.com/english/hill/</ref> '''Salute''' ''it.'', from ''lat.'' Salvs, an ancient Roman demi-goddess<ref>Latin Dictionary http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=salus</ref> or ''[[sancus|semo]]'', ultimately from ''PIE'' solh₂, meaning whole or completed<ref>https://en.m.wiktionary.org/wiki/salvus</ref>
'''[[Cippi]]''', ''gr.'' ἐνσκήπτω, ''n.'' stela, a balance, a post;<ref>Latin Dictionary http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=scapus</ref> ''v.'' to let fall, to hurl (''viz.'' a rock)<ref>A Greek- English Lexicon http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0057:entry=skh/ptw</ref>
'''[[Sancus|Semo]]''' pl. '''Semones''', ''gr.'' Δαίμων, demigods and -goddesses<ref>An Intermediate Greek-Roman Lexicon http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0058:entry=dai/mwn</ref> of Sabini origin,<ref>Paganalia http://www.novaroma.org/nr/Paganalia</ref> from ''lat.'' '''se''', separated, parted from<ref>Online Etymology Dictionary http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?allowed_in_frame=0&search=se-</ref> '''+''' ''lat.'' '''homo''', as one, together with<ref>Online Etymology Dictionary http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=homo-</ref>
'''Dáphnē Laures''', ''lat.'' Laurūs, from ''etr.'' lar, the spirit of; ''anc. gr.'' Δάφνη δáphnē, laurel, of which the ingested leaves give the gift of prophesying<ref>A Latin Dictionary, (''laurūs'', L. nobilis, C. camphor, ''see'' Cic. Mur. 41.) http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus:text:1999.04.0059:entry=laurus</ref>
